column1: #FORMAT=WebAnno TSV 3.2
#T_SP=webanno.custom.Referent|entity|infstat
#T_RL=webanno.custom.Coref|type|BT_webanno.custom.Referent
#Text=THE MILLENNIUM FULCRUM EDITION , 1988
#Text=A man stood upon a railroad bridge in northern Alabama , looking down into the swift water twenty feet below .
#Text=The man 's hands were behind his back , the wrists bound with a cord .
#Text=A rope closely encircled his neck .
#Text=It was attached to a stout cross-timber above his head and the slack fell to the level of his knees .

#Text=Some loose boards laid upon the ties supporting the rails of the railway supplied a footing for him and his executioners -- two private soldiers of the Federal army , directed by a sergeant who in civil life may have been a deputy sheriff .
#Text=At a short remove upon the same temporary platform was an officer in the uniform of his rank , armed .
#Text=He was a captain .

#Text=A sentinel at each end of the bridge stood with his rifle in the position known as " support , " that is to say , vertical in front of the left shoulder , the hammer resting on the forearm thrown straight across the chest -- a formal and unnatural position , enforcing an erect carriage of the body .
#Text=It did not appear to be the duty of these two men to know what was occurring at the center of the bridge ; they merely blockaded the two ends of the foot planking that traversed it .
#Text=Beyond one of the sentinels nobody was in sight ; the railroad ran straight away into a forest for a hundred yards , then , curving , was lost to view .
#Text=Doubtless there was an outpost farther along .

#Text=The other bank of the stream was open ground -- a gentle slope topped with a stockade of vertical tree trunks , loopholed for rifles , with a single embrasure through which protruded the muzzle of a brass cannon commanding the bridge .

#Text=Midway up the slope between the bridge and fort were the spectators -- a single company of infantry in line , at " parade rest , " the butts of their rifles on the ground , the barrels inclining slightly backward against the right shoulder , the hands crossed upon the stock .

column1: #Text=A lieutenant stood at the right of the line , the point of his sword upon the ground , his left hand resting upon his right .
#Text=Excepting the group of four at the center of the bridge , not a man moved .
#Text=The company faced the bridge , staring stonily , motionless .
#Text=The sentinels , facing the banks of the stream , might have been statues to adorn the bridge .
#Text=The captain stood with folded arms , silent , observing the work of his subordinates , but making no sign .
#Text=Death is a dignitary who when he comes announced is to be received with formal manifestations of respect , even by those most familiar with him .
#Text=In the code of military etiquette silence and fixity are forms of deference .
#Text=The man who was engaged in being hanged was apparently about thirty-five years of age .
#Text=He was a civilian , if one might judge from his habit , which was that of a planter .

#Text=His features were good -- a straight nose , firm mouth , broad forehead , from which his long , dark hair was combed straight back , falling behind his ears to the collar of his well fitting frock coat .

#Text=He wore a moustache and pointed beard , but no whiskers ; his eyes were large and dark gray , and had a kindly expression which one would hardly have expected in one whose neck was in the hemp .
#Text=Evidently this was no vulgar assassin .
#Text=The liberal military code makes provision for hanging many kinds of persons , and gentlemen are not excluded .
#Text=The preparations being complete , the two private soldiers stepped aside and each drew away the plank upon which he had been standing .
#Text=The sergeant turned to the captain , saluted and placed himself immediately behind that officer , who in turn moved apart one pace .
#Text=These movements left the condemned man and the sergeant standing on the two ends of the same plank , which spanned three of the cross-ties of the bridge .
#Text=The end upon which the civilian stood almost , but not quite , reached a fourth .
#Text=This plank had been held in place by the weight of the captain ; it was now held by that of the sergeant .
#Text=At a signal from the former the latter would step aside , the plank would tilt and the condemned man go down between two ties .
#Text=The arrangement commended itself to his judgement as simple and effective .
#Text=His face had not been covered nor his eyes bandaged .
#Text=He looked a moment at his " unsteadfast footing , " then let his gaze wander to the swirling water of the stream racing madly beneath his feet .
#Text=A piece of dancing driftwood caught his attention and his eyes followed it down the current .
#Text=How slowly it appeared to move !
#Text=What a sluggish stream !
#Text=He closed his eyes in order to fix his last thoughts upon his wife and children .
#Text=The water , touched to gold by the early sun , the brooding mists under the banks at some distance down the stream , the fort , the soldiers , the piece of drift -- all had distracted him .
#Text=And now he became conscious of a new disturbance .

#Text=Striking through the thought of his dear ones was sound which he could neither ignore nor understand , a sharp , distinct , metallic percussion like the stroke of a blacksmith 's hammer upon the anvil ; it had the same ringing quality .
#Text=He wondered what it was , and whether immeasurably distant or near by -- it seemed both .
#Text=Its recurrence was regular , but as slow as the tolling of a death knell .
#Text=He awaited each new stroke with impatience and -- he knew not why -- apprehension .
#Text=The intervals of silence grew progressively longer ; the delays became maddening .
#Text=With their greater infrequency the sounds increased in strength and sharpness .
#Text=They hurt his ear like the thrust of a knife ; he feared he would shriek .
#Text=What he heard was the ticking of his watch .
